title: CLAUDE.md
text: R package maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) series system parameters masked component failure data. package implements likelihood models systems : - Component lifetimes may masked (right-censored) - Component cause failure masked via candidate sets (subsets components plausibly contain failed component) - Masking conditions C1, C2, C3 satisfied

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # Install dependencies (including GitHub remotes) Rscript -e "devtools::install_deps(dependencies = TRUE)"  # Load package for interactive development Rscript -e "devtools::load_all()"  # Generate documentation from roxygen2 comments Rscript -e "devtools::document()"  # Run all tests Rscript -e "devtools::test()"  # Run a specific test file Rscript -e "devtools::test(filter = 'exp_series_md')"  # Run tests with coverage Rscript -e "covr::package_coverage()"  # Run R CMD check Rscript -e "devtools::check()"  # Build pkgdown site Rscript -e "pkgdown::build_site()"

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Three likelihood model classes, using S3 generic dispatch: model implements S3 methods: loglik(), score(), hess_loglik(), assumptions(), rdata() S3 class hierarchy (multiple inheritance dispatch): Implementation note: exponential model computes score Hessian analytically. Weibull models compute score analytically use numDeriv::jacobian score Hessian. Usage pattern:
code: c("exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3", "series_md", "likelihood_model") c("wei_series_md_c1_c2_c3", "series_md", "likelihood_model") c("wei_series_homogeneous_md_c1_c2_c3", "series_md", "likelihood_model") model <- exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3() ll_fn <- loglik(model)     # Returns function(df, par, ...) s_fn <- score(model)       # Returns function(df, par, ...) H_fn <- hess_loglik(model) # Returns function(df, par, ...) gen_fn <- rdata(model)     # Returns function(theta, n, tau, p, ...)  # Evaluate ll_value <- ll_fn(df, par = c(0.5, 0.3, 0.2))  # Generate simulated masked data df <- gen_fn(theta = c(0.5, 0.3, 0.2), n = 100, tau = 10, p = 0.5)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: C1: Failed component candidate set probability 1 C2: Uniform probability candidate sets conditioned component cause C3: Masking probabilities independent system parameters

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Generate component lifetimes (t1, t2, ...) Apply md_series_lifetime_right_censoring() ‚Üí adds t, delta Apply md_bernoulli_cand_c1_c2_c3() ‚Üí adds q1, q2, ... Apply md_cand_sampler() ‚Üí adds x1, x2, ... Fit model using t x1, x2, ... columns

title: CLAUDE.md
text: t1, t2, ..., tm: Component lifetimes (latent) t: System lifetime (observed) delta: Right-censoring indicator (TRUE = exact, FALSE = censored) q1, q2, ..., qm: Candidate set probabilities (latent) x1, x2, ..., xm: Boolean candidate set indicators (observed)

text: straightforward series system estimate series system exponentially distributed component lifetimes. Suppose exponential series system mm components parameterized following R code: , study, Œ∏=(1,1.1,0.95,1.15,1.1)‚Ä≤\theta = (1, 1.1, 0.95, 1.15, 1.1)'. component assigned index jj exponentially distributed lifetime failure rate Œ∏j\theta_j, e.g., Œ∏2=1.1\theta_2 = 1.1 failure rate component indexed 22. Let‚Äôs simulate generating lifetimes m=5m = 5 components series system: Next, use function md_series_lifetime_right_censoring decorate masked data right-censor-censoring time chosen probability Pr{Ti>œÑ}=0.75\Pr\{T_i > \tau\} = 0.75:
code: theta <- c(1,     # component 1 failure rate            1.1,   # 3            0.95,  # 5            1.15,  # 6            1.1)   # 7  m <- length(theta) set.seed(7231) # set seed for reproducibility n <- 7500 comp_times <- matrix(nrow=n,ncol=m) for (j in 1:m)     comp_times[,j] <- rexp(n,theta[j]) comp_times <- md_encode_matrix(comp_times,"t") print(comp_times,n=4) #> # A tibble: 7,500 √ó 5 #>      t1     t2    t3     t4    t5 #>   <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> #> 1  2.95 1.67   0.777 0.0476 0.380 #> 2  1.10 2.20   2.59  3.27   0.626 #> 3  1.20 0.0956 3.74  1.80   2.13  #> 4  1.44 0.0460 0.123 0.522  0.102 #> # ‚Ñπ 7,496 more rows q <- 0.25 tau <- rep(-(1/sum(theta))*log(q),n) data <- comp_times %>% md_series_lifetime_right_censoring(tau) print(data,n=4,drop_latent=TRUE) #> Latent variables:  t1 t2 t3 t4 t5  #> # A tibble: 7,500 √ó 2 #>        t delta #>    <dbl> <lgl> #> 1 0.0476 TRUE  #> 2 0.262  FALSE #> 3 0.0956 TRUE  #> 4 0.0460 TRUE  #> # ‚Ñπ 7,496 more rows

text: set solutions MLE equations must stationary points, .e., point score function type ‚Ñùm‚Ü¶‚Ñùm\mathbb{R}^m \mapsto \mathbb{R}^m zero. jj-th component output score function given ‚àÇ‚Ñì‚àÇŒªp=‚àë=1n(‚àëj‚ààciŒªj)‚àí11{p‚ààci Œ¥i=0}‚àí‚àë=1nsi.\begin{equation} \label{eq:score_expo_j} \frac{\partial \ell}{\partial \lambda_p} =    \sum_{=1}^{n} \biggl( \sum_{j \c_i} \lambda_j \biggr)^{-1}   1_{\{p \c_i \text{ } \delta_i = 0\}} - \sum_{=1}^{n} s_i. \end{equation} may find MLE solving maximum likelihood equation , .e., set (stationary) points satisfying ‚àÇ‚Ñì‚àÇŒªj|ŒªÃÇj=0 \frac{\partial \ell}{\partial \lambda_j}\Biggr|_{\hat\lambda_j} = 0  j=1,‚Ä¶,mj=1,\ldots,m. approximate solution problem using iterative Newton-Raphson method described Section . Newton-Raphson method needs observed information matrix, function Œª\lambda type ‚Ñùm‚Ü¶‚Ñùm√óm\mathbb{R}^m \mapsto \mathbb{R}^{m \times m}. (j,k)(j,k)-th element J(Œª)J(\lambda) given ‚àÇ2‚Ñì‚àÇŒªj‚àÇŒªk=‚àë=1n(‚àëj‚ààciŒªj)‚àí21{j,k‚ààci Œ¥i=0}.\begin{equation} \label{eq:info_expo} \frac{\partial^2 \ell}{\partial \lambda_j \partial \lambda_k} =    \sum_{=1}^{n} \biggl( \sum_{j \c_i} \lambda_j \biggr)^{-2}   1_{\{j,k \c_i \text{ } \delta_i = 0\}}. \end{equation}

what: Log-likelihood of Œ∏\theta given masked data
title: Masked Data Likelihood Model: Components with Exponentially Distributed Lifetimes Arranged In Series Configuration
text: reduced log-likelihood function (log kernel likelihood function) given ‚Ñì(Œ∏|data)=‚àí(‚àë=1nti)(‚àëj=1mŒ∏j)+‚àë=1n(1‚àíŒ¥i)log(‚àëj‚ààciŒ∏j). \ell(\theta|\text{data}) =     -\left(\sum_{=1}^{n} t_i\right)     \left(\sum_{j=1}^{m} \theta_j\right) +     \sum_{=1}^{n} (1-\delta_i)\log\left(\sum_{j \c_i} \theta_j\right). compute log-likelihood function using generic dispatch: returned function ll(df, par) evaluates log-likelihood parameter par given data df. example, true parameter value: Note implementation uses minimally sufficient statistics, improves computational efficiency. log-likelihood function contains maximum amount information parameter Œ∏\theta given sample masked data data satisfying conditions C1C_1, C2C_2, C3C_3. Suppose know Œ∏=(1,1.1,0.95,1.15,1.1)‚Ä≤\theta = (1, 1.1, 0.95, 1.15, 1.1)'. log-likelihood, may estimate Œ∏\theta Œ∏ÃÇ\hat\theta solving Œ∏ÃÇ=argmaxŒ∏‚ààŒ©‚Ñì(Œ∏), \hat{\theta} = \operatorname{argmax}_{\theta \\Omega} \ell(\theta),  .e., finding point maximizes log-likelihood observed sample data. known maximum likelihood estimation (MLE). typically solve MLE solving ‚àá‚Ñì|Œ∏=Œ∏ÃÇ=0. \nabla \ell|_{\theta=\hat{\theta}} = 0. popular choice gradient ascent, iterative method based update rule Œ∏(n+1)=Œ∏n+Œ∑‚Ñì(Œ∏n), \theta^{(n+1)} = \theta^n + \eta \ell(\theta^n),  Œ∑\eta learning rate. can also obtain score (gradient) function via generic dispatch: score true parameter close zero (MLE, exactly zero): likelihood.model framework provides analytical score Hessian implementations available, falling back numerical differentiation otherwise. follows, use algebraic.mle help solve MLE equations display various properties solution. solve MLE equation, use generic fit() function, dispatches fit.likelihood_model object "likelihood_model" class. fit() function returns solver uses optim internally BFGS method default. result mle object algebraic.mle package rich accessor methods: can access specific components MLE: Recall true parameter Œ∏=(1,1.1,0.95,1.15,1.1)‚Ä≤\theta = (1, 1.1, 0.95, 1.15, 1.1)'. Due sampling variability, different runs experiment result different outcomes, .e., Œ∏ÃÇ\hat{\theta} sampling distribution. see Œ∏ÃÇ‚â†Œ∏\hat{\theta} \neq \theta, reasonably close. may measure sampling variability using variance-covariance matrix, bias, mean squared error (MSE), confidence intervals.

ll <- loglik(model) ll(data, theta) #> [1] -1393 grad <- score(model) grad(data, theta) #> [1] -23.934  -4.920  -9.392 -21.984  -2.042 # Get the solver from the model using generic dispatch solver <- fit(model)  # Solve for MLE with initial guess theta0 <- rep(1, m) estimate <- solver(data, par = theta0, method = "Nelder-Mead") # Print summary with confidence intervals print(estimate) #> Maximum Likelihood Estimate (Fisherian) #> ---------------------------------------- #> Coefficients: #> [1] 0.9617 1.1049 0.9455 1.1147 1.1116 #>  #> Log-likelihood: -1392  #> Observations: 7500 # Point estimate theta.hat <- estimate$par cat("MLE:", round(theta.hat, 4), "
") #> MLE: 0.9617 1.105 0.9455 1.115 1.112  # Standard errors (sqrt of diagonal of variance-covariance matrix) cat("SE:", round(sqrt(diag(estimate$vcov)), 4), "
") #> SE: 0.0442 0.0457 0.0427 0.0449 0.0454  # Log-likelihood at MLE cat("Log-likelihood:", round(estimate$loglik, 4), "
") #> Log-likelihood: -1392

title: Masked Data Likelihood Model: Components with Exponentially Distributed Lifetimes Arranged In Series Configuration
text: understand sampling properties MLE, conduct Monte Carlo simulation study. repeatedly: Generate masked data true model Fit likelihood model obtain Œ∏ÃÇ\hat{\theta} Compute asymptotic confidence intervals collection estimates, can compute: Bias: E[Œ∏ÃÇ]‚àíŒ∏\text{E}[\hat{\theta}] - \theta Variance: Var[Œ∏ÃÇ]\text{Var}[\hat{\theta}] MSE: E[(Œ∏ÃÇ‚àíŒ∏)2]=Bias2+Var\text{E}[(\hat{\theta} - \theta)^2] = \text{Bias}^2 + \text{Var} Coverage probability: Proportion CIs containing true value
code: set.seed(7231)  # Simulation parameters B <- 200       # Number of Monte Carlo replications alpha <- 0.05  # Significance level for CIs  # Storage for results estimates <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = m) se_estimates <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = m) ci_lower <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = m) ci_upper <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = m) converged <- logical(B) for (b in 1:B) {     # Generate component lifetimes     comp_times_b <- matrix(nrow = n, ncol = m)     for (j in 1:m) {         comp_times_b[, j] <- rexp(n, theta[j])     }     comp_times_b <- md_encode_matrix(comp_times_b, "t")      # Apply masking pipeline     data_b <- comp_times_b %>%         md_series_lifetime_right_censoring(tau) %>%         md_bernoulli_cand_c1_c2_c3(p) %>%         md_cand_sampler()      # Fit model     tryCatch({         result_b <- solver(data_b, par = theta0, method = "Nelder-Mead")         estimates[b, ] <- result_b$par         se_estimates[b, ] <- sqrt(diag(result_b$vcov))          # Asymptotic Wald CIs         z <- qnorm(1 - alpha/2)         ci_lower[b, ] <- result_b$par - z * sqrt(diag(result_b$vcov))         ci_upper[b, ] <- result_b$par + z * sqrt(diag(result_b$vcov))         converged[b] <- result_b$converged     }, error = function(e) {         converged[b] <<- FALSE     }) }  cat("Convergence rate:", mean(converged, na.rm = TRUE), "\n")

Bias %"))

text: asymptotic (1‚àíŒ±)(1-\alpha)% Wald confidence interval : Œ∏ÃÇj¬±z1‚àíŒ±/2‚ãÖSE(Œ∏ÃÇj) \hat{\theta}_j \pm z_{1-\alpha/2} \cdot \text{SE}(\hat{\theta}_j) assess coverage probability: proportion intervals contain true parameter value. Coverage Probability 95% Confidence Intervals
code: # Compute coverage for each component coverage <- numeric(m) for (j in 1:m) {     valid_j <- valid & !is.na(ci_lower[, j]) & !is.na(ci_upper[, j])     covered <- (ci_lower[valid_j, j] <= theta[j]) & (theta[j] <= ci_upper[valid_j, j])     coverage[j] <- mean(covered) }  # Mean CI width mean_width <- colMeans(ci_upper[valid, ] - ci_lower[valid, ], na.rm = TRUE)  coverage_df <- data.frame(     Component = 1:m,     True = theta,     Coverage = coverage,     Nominal = 1 - alpha,     Mean_Width = mean_width )  knitr::kable(coverage_df, digits = 4,              caption = paste0("Coverage Probability of ", 100*(1-alpha), "% Confidence Intervals"),              col.names = c("Component", "True Œ∏", "Coverage", "Nominal", "Mean Width"))

text: Monte Carlo simulation (n=7500n = 7500, B=200B = 200, p=0.3p = 0.3, ‚àº25%\sim 25\% censoring) demonstrates MLE exponential series system masked data satisfying conditions C1‚ÄìC3 desirable large-sample properties: Essentially unbiased. relative biases 0.7%, largest component 5 0.67%. squared-bias contribution MSE negligible (e.g., component 1: bias2‚âà2√ó10‚àí7\text{bias}^2 \approx 2 \times 10^{-7} vs Var=0.0019\text{Var} = 0.0019). MLE consistent approximately unbiased sample size. Uniform relative precision. RMSE ranges 0.043 0.046 across components ‚Äî roughly 4‚Äì5% true rates. uniformity consistent asymptotic efficiency MLE: components higher failure rates (thus higher variance) also proportionally wider CIs. Coverage near nominal. Coverage ranges 93.4% 96.5% nominal 95%. Component 4 (93.4%) slightly undercovers, suggesting Wald interval may mildly liberal components sample size. known finite-sample property Wald intervals rate parameters. CI width design metric. Mean CI widths 0.170‚Äì0.180 (¬±8.5%\pm 8.5\% true rate) provide concrete basis sample size planning. Since CI width scales 1/n1/\sqrt{n}, halving width requires roughly 4√ó4\times sample size.

text: MLE properties depend several factors: sample size, masking probability, right-censoring rate. section, study factors affect estimation accuracy.

title: Masked Data Likelihood Model: Components with Exponentially Distributed Lifetimes Arranged In Series Configuration
text: masking probability pp controls much information failed component obscured. p=0p = 0, failed component candidate set (perfect information). pp increases, non-failed components included, making estimation difficult.  Effect Masking Probability Estimation Accuracy simulation reveals several patterns masking degrades estimation quality: MSE increases monotonically 0.015 (p=0p = 0) 0.062 (p=0.5p = 0.5) ‚Äî 4.2√ó4.2\times degradation. RMSE roughly doubles 0.12 0.25, meaning typical estimation error doubles moving unmasked maximally masked candidate sets. Variance drives degradation, bias. Mean |bias||\text{bias}| fluctuates 0.008 0.026 systematic trend, variance grows steadily pp. consistent theoretical result conditions C1‚ÄìC3 preserve unbiasedness MLE ‚Äî masking erodes precision without introducing systematic error. marginal cost masking accelerates. MSE roughly doubles p=0p = 0 p=0.3p = 0.3 (0.015‚Üí0.0330.015 \0.033), roughly doubles p=0.3p = 0.3 p=0.5p = 0.5 (0.033‚Üí0.0620.033 \0.062). practitioners, means moderate masking (p‚â§0.3p \leq 0.3) far less costly heavy masking. Residual MSE p=0p = 0. Even masking non-failed components, MSE 0.015 remains due right-censoring alone ‚Äî useful baseline isolating censoring contribution.
code: set.seed(7231)  # Use smaller sample for sensitivity study n_sens <- 500 B_sens <- 100  # Masking probabilities to test p_values <- seq(0, 0.5, by = 0.1)  # Fixed right-censoring (25% censored) q_sens <- 0.25 tau_sens <- rep(-(1/sum(theta))*log(q_sens), n_sens)  # Storage mask_results <- list() for (p_idx in seq_along(p_values)) {     p_curr <- p_values[p_idx]     est_p <- matrix(NA, nrow = B_sens, ncol = m)      for (b in 1:B_sens) {         # Generate data         comp_b <- matrix(nrow = n_sens, ncol = m)         for (j in 1:m) comp_b[, j] <- rexp(n_sens, theta[j])         comp_b <- md_encode_matrix(comp_b, "t")          data_b <- comp_b %>%             md_series_lifetime_right_censoring(tau_sens) %>%             md_bernoulli_cand_c1_c2_c3(p_curr) %>%             md_cand_sampler()          tryCatch({             fit_b <- solver(data_b, par = theta0, method = "Nelder-Mead")             if (fit_b$converged) est_p[b, ] <- fit_b$par         }, error = function(e) NULL)     }      # Compute statistics     valid_p <- !is.na(est_p[, 1])     mask_results[[p_idx]] <- list(         p = p_curr,         bias = colMeans(est_p[valid_p, , drop = FALSE]) - theta,         variance = apply(est_p[valid_p, , drop = FALSE], 2, var),         mse = (colMeans(est_p[valid_p, , drop = FALSE]) - theta)^2 +               apply(est_p[valid_p, , drop = FALSE], 2, var)     ) } # Extract bias and MSE for plotting bias_mat <- sapply(mask_results, function(x) mean(abs(x$bias))) mse_mat <- sapply(mask_results, function(x) mean(x$mse))  par(mfrow = c(1, 2), mar = c(4, 4, 2, 1))  # Mean absolute bias vs masking probability plot(p_values, bias_mat, type = "b", pch = 19, col = "blue",      xlab = "Masking Probability (p)",      ylab = "Mean Absolute Bias",      main = "Bias vs Masking Probability") grid()  # Mean MSE vs masking probability plot(p_values, mse_mat, type = "b", pch = 19, col = "red",      xlab = "Masking Probability (p)",      ylab = "Mean MSE",      main = "MSE vs Masking Probability") grid() mask_df <- data.frame(     p = p_values,     Mean_Abs_Bias = bias_mat,     Mean_MSE = mse_mat,     Mean_RMSE = sqrt(mse_mat) )  knitr::kable(mask_df, digits = 4,              caption = "Effect of Masking Probability on Estimation Accuracy",              col.names = c("Masking Prob.", "Mean |Bias|", "Mean MSE", "Mean RMSE"))

title: Masked Data Likelihood Model: Components with Exponentially Distributed Lifetimes Arranged In Series Configuration
text: Right-censoring reduces number exact failure times observed. system right-censored, know system survived beyond censoring time, don‚Äôt observe actual failure time failed component.  Effect Right-Censoring Rate Estimation Accuracy simulation reveals censoring dominant source information loss model: MSE grows 0.019 (10% censored) 0.183 (90% censored) ‚Äî 9.5√ó9.5\times degradation, far exceeding 4.2√ó4.2\times range masking. Censoring damaging eliminates failure time candidate set, whereas masking dilutes candidate set. Clear inflection around 50% censoring. MSE still manageable 50% (0.0400.040) jumps 0.0590.059 70% 0.1830.183 90%. relationship censoring rate MSE convex ‚Äî additional percentage point censoring damaging last. Bias remains modest even extreme censoring. Mean |bias||\text{bias}| grows 0.005 (10% censoring) 0.034 (90% censoring) stays small relative true rates (‚àº3%\sim 3\% worst). MLE remains approximately unbiased ‚Äî consistent increasingly inefficient. Robustness extreme censoring. 90% censoring, ‚àº50\sim 50 500 observations exact failures, yet MLE still converges. resulting estimates imprecise (RMSE ‚âà0.43\approx 0.43, ‚àº40%\sim 40\% true rates), likelihood-based approach remains functional.
code: set.seed(7231)  # Censoring quantiles (proportion surviving past tau) # q = 0.1 means 10% survive past tau (light censoring, ~10% censored) # q = 0.9 means 90% survive past tau (heavy censoring, ~90% censored) q_values <- seq(0.1, 0.9, by = 0.1)  # Survival probabilities (matches simulation framework)  # Fixed masking probability p_cens <- 0.2  # Storage cens_results <- list() for (q_idx in seq_along(q_values)) {     q_curr <- q_values[q_idx]     tau_curr <- rep(-(1/sum(theta))*log(q_curr), n_sens)     est_q <- matrix(NA, nrow = B_sens, ncol = m)      for (b in 1:B_sens) {         # Generate data         comp_b <- matrix(nrow = n_sens, ncol = m)         for (j in 1:m) comp_b[, j] <- rexp(n_sens, theta[j])         comp_b <- md_encode_matrix(comp_b, "t")          data_b <- comp_b %>%             md_series_lifetime_right_censoring(tau_curr) %>%             md_bernoulli_cand_c1_c2_c3(p_cens) %>%             md_cand_sampler()          tryCatch({             fit_b <- solver(data_b, par = theta0, method = "Nelder-Mead")             if (fit_b$converged) est_q[b, ] <- fit_b$par         }, error = function(e) NULL)     }      # Compute statistics     valid_q <- !is.na(est_q[, 1])     cens_rate <- 1 - mean(data_b$delta)  # Actual censoring rate     cens_results[[q_idx]] <- list(         q = q_curr,         cens_rate = cens_rate,         bias = colMeans(est_q[valid_q, , drop = FALSE]) - theta,         variance = apply(est_q[valid_q, , drop = FALSE], 2, var),         mse = (colMeans(est_q[valid_q, , drop = FALSE]) - theta)^2 +               apply(est_q[valid_q, , drop = FALSE], 2, var)     ) } # Extract statistics cens_rates <- sapply(cens_results, function(x) x$cens_rate) bias_cens <- sapply(cens_results, function(x) mean(abs(x$bias))) mse_cens <- sapply(cens_results, function(x) mean(x$mse))  par(mfrow = c(1, 2), mar = c(4, 4, 2, 1))  # Mean absolute bias vs censoring rate plot(cens_rates * 100, bias_cens, type = "b", pch = 19, col = "blue",      xlab = "Censoring Rate (%)",      ylab = "Mean Absolute Bias",      main = "Bias vs Censoring Rate") grid()  # Mean MSE vs censoring rate plot(cens_rates * 100, mse_cens, type = "b", pch = 19, col = "red",      xlab = "Censoring Rate (%)",      ylab = "Mean MSE",      main = "MSE vs Censoring Rate") grid() cens_df <- data.frame(     Cens_Rate_Pct = round(cens_rates * 100, 1),     Mean_Abs_Bias = bias_cens,     Mean_MSE = mse_cens,     Mean_RMSE = sqrt(mse_cens) )  knitr::kable(cens_df, digits = 4,              caption = "Effect of Right-Censoring Rate on Estimation Accuracy",              col.names = c("Censoring %", "Mean |Bias|", "Mean MSE", "Mean RMSE"))

title: Masked Data Likelihood Model: Components with Exponentially Distributed Lifetimes Arranged In Series Configuration
text: Based sensitivity analyses: Prioritize reducing censoring masking. Censoring degrades MSE 9.5√ó9.5\times across range versus 4.2√ó4.2\times masking. experimental design, extending observation window reduce censoring 50% yields larger gains improving diagnostic resolution reduce masking. Moderate masking tolerable. MSE doubles p=0p = 0 p=0.3p = 0.3. reducing masking probability 0.3 requires expensive diagnostic equipment, incremental benefit may justify cost. 50% censoring threshold. ‚àº50%\sim 50\% censoring, estimation quality degrades gradually. , MSE grows convexly ‚Äî avoid experimental designs half systems survive past observation window. CI widths sample size planning. n=7500n = 7500 p=0.3p = 0.3 25% censoring, 95% CI widths ‚àº0.17\sim 0.17 rates near 1.0. Width scales 1/n1/\sqrt{n}, n=1875n = 1875 gives widths ‚àº0.34\sim 0.34 (double), n=30000n = 30000 gives ‚àº0.085\sim 0.085 (half).

title: Likelihood Models for Series Systems with Masked Component Cause of Failure
code: library(likelihood.model.series.md)  # --- Exponential model --- model <- exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3()  # Generate masked series data gen <- rdata(model) df <- gen(theta = c(1.0, 1.1, 0.95), n = 500, tau = 3, p = 0.3)  # Fit via MLE solver <- fit(model) mle <- solver(df, par = c(1, 1, 1)) mle$theta.hat   # estimated rates mle$sigma       # asymptotic standard errors  # Log-likelihood, score, and Hessian ll <- loglik(model) s  <- score(model) H  <- hess_loglik(model)  ll(df, par = mle$theta.hat) s(df, par = mle$theta.hat) H(df, par = mle$theta.hat)  # --- Weibull model (shared shape) --- wmodel <- wei_series_homogeneous_md_c1_c2_c3() wsolver <- fit(wmodel) # theta: (shape, scale1, scale2, ...) # wmle <- wsolver(data, par = c(1.2, 1000, 900, 850))

title: Constructs a likelihood model for exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3. ‚Äî exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3
text: model satisfies concept likelihood_model likelihood.model package providing following methods: (1) loglik.exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3 (2) score.exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3 (3) hess_loglik.exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3 useful maximum likelihood estimation, hypothesis testing (e.g., likelihood ratio test), estimation asymptotic sampling distribution given data DGP according specified model, etc. designed work well likelihood_model R package. particular, intended used likelihood_contr_model object, likelihood_model object allows likelihood contributions added whatever data model mind. likelihood model, masked component data approximately satisfies following conditions: C1: Pr{K[] C[]) = 1 C2: Pr{C[]=c[] | K[]=j, T[]=t[]) = Pr(C[]=c[] | K[]=j', T[]=t[]) j, j' c[]. C3: masking probabilities independent theta special case, model also includes exact component cause failure data candidate set singleton.

title: Constructs a likelihood model for wei_series_homogeneous_md_c1_c2_c3. ‚Äî wei_series_homogeneous_md_c1_c2_c3
text: reduced model components share common shape parameter k, retaining individual scale parameters. parameter vector (k, scale_1, ..., scale_m), giving m+1 parameters instead 2m. key property model series system lifetime Weibull distributed shape k scale lambda_s = (sum(scale_j^-k))^-1/k. model satisfies concept likelihood_model likelihood.model package providing following methods: (1) loglik.wei_series_homogeneous_md_c1_c2_c3 (2) score.wei_series_homogeneous_md_c1_c2_c3 (3) hess_loglik.wei_series_homogeneous_md_c1_c2_c3 likelihood model, masked component data approximately satisfies: C1: Pr{K[] C[]} = 1 C2: Pr{C[]=c[] | K[]=j, T[]=t[]} = Pr{C[]=c[] | K[]=j', T[]=t[]} j, j' c[]. C3: masking probabilities independent theta
